Yes, I agree that American Public Schools are massive failure. LOL did you know that 11% of American children 18-24 cannot point out the United States on a map of the world? Compare these individuals to European children who are doing college physics in the 8th grade and starting to learn their third language in the 9th grade. Anyway, yes it is obvious to me that INTEGRATION and the social engineering of the federal government has been a colossal embarrassing failure. Here is the article.
 
 http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/11/1120_021120_GeoRoperSurvey.html
 
 
In a nation called the world's superpower, only 17 percent of young adults in the United States could find Afghanistan on a map, according to a new worldwide survey released today. 
 
 The young U.S. citizens received poor marks generally in geography. But then, as results showed, their counterparts in other countries were hardly star students. 
 
 The National Geographic-Roper 2002 Global Geographic Literacy Survey polled more than 3,000 18- to 24-year-olds in Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Sweden and the United States. 
 
 
 John Fahey, President and CEO of the National Geographic Society, presented results of the The National Geographic-2002 Global Geographic Literacy Survey, which polled more than 3,000 18- to-24-year-olds in Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Sweden and the United States.
 
 Sweden scored highest; Mexico, lowest. The U.S. was next to last. 
 
 "The survey demonstrates the geographic illiteracy of the United States," said Robert Pastor, professor of International Relations at American University, in Washington, D.C. "The results are particularly appalling in light of September 11, which traumatized America and revealed that our destiny is connected to the rest of the world." 
 
 About 11 percent of young citizens of the U.S. couldn't even locate the U.S. on a map. The Pacific Ocean's location was a mystery to 29 percent; Japan, to 58 percent; France, to 65 percent; and the United Kingdom, to 69 percent. 
 
 Are Young U.S. Citizens Americentric? 
 
 Despite the threat of war in Iraq and the daily reports of suicide bombers in Israel, less than 15 percent of the young U.S. citizens could locate either country. 
 
 More young U.S. citizens in the study knew that the island featured in last season's TV show "Survivor" is in the South Pacific than could find Israel. 
 
 Particularly humiliating was that all countries were better able to identify the U.S. population than many young U.S. citizens. Within the U.S., almost one-third said that population was between one billion and two billion; the answer is 289 million. 
 
 "It gives the sense that there is this Americentric thing going on-that we are big and powerful and have all these people in our country," said John Fahey, President and CEO of the National Geographic Society. 
 
 On the other hand, Pastor suggests that the results could mean that most young Americans just have no idea of the total world population (about six billion). 
 
 Poor Geographic Literacy Worldwide 
 
 Young adults worldwide are not markedly more literate about geography than the Americans. 
 
 On average, fewer than 25 percent of young people worldwide could locate Israel on the map. Only about 20 percent could identify hotspots like Afghanistan, Iran and Iraq. 
 
 Of all the young adults in the survey, only about one-third in Germany, Sweden and Japan, could name four countries that officially acknowledge having nuclear weapons. In the rest of the countries that number dropped to less than a quarter. In France 24 percent did not know that that their own country was a nuclear nation. 
 
 The survey results are not all bleak, says Roger Downs, head of the geography department at Pennsylvania State University, in State College, and a National Geographic geographer-in-residence in 1995-1996. 
 
 Geography Not Valued in Schools 
 
 Since the last Geographic-sponsored survey in 1988, said Downs, the percentage of young U.S. citizens who reported taking a geography course in school rose from 30 to 55 percent. And students who had studied geography did better on the current survey. 
 
 U.S. schools generally have slighted geography. "If geography is not in the curriculum," Downs said, "it's not tested-and that says to the students that it is not valued." 
 
 The schools are not solely to blame, either. "Wouldn't it be nice if parents also read atlases to their children?" Downs says. 
 
 Questions covering current events or practical activities yielded more promising results. 
 
 Most young U.S. citizens knew that Africa was most affected by the AIDS epidemic, and about half knew that El Niño caused erratic weather. 
 
 "When geography and life intersect, people pay attention," said Nick Boyon, senior vice president for international research at RoperASW, in Manhattan. 
 
 Boosting Geography 
 
 Geographic knowledge increases through travel and language proficiency, among other factors. 
 
 In the highest-scoring countries-Sweden, Germany and Italy-at least 70 percent of the young adults had traveled internationally in the last three years, and the majority spoke more than one language (in Sweden, 92 and 89 percent, respectively). 
 
 In the U.S. and Mexico only about 20 percent had traveled abroad during the same period and the majority spoke only one language. 
 
 To fight geographic ignorance, and apathy, among young people in the U.S. and around the world, the National Geographic Society will convene an international coalition of leaders in American business, education and media. 
 
 Next year the panel will recommend initiatives to policymakers in those areas-and to parents and children.

Let's look at the school side. The county I live in, about 78,000 people, pays teachers an average of $52,000 per year. It's considered above the norm and subsequently has virtually no turnover. Every outside analysis has
 reported favorably on professional abilities of the teachers. Teacher to student ratio is 1:21. 
 
 Using state standards, all 10th grade students undergo testing to determine if they meet or exceed grade-level standards. In 2003 only 50% of 10th graders met or exceeded math standards, while only 49% met or exceeded reading standards. 
 
 Pretty pathetic. School boards here are dominated by long-term residents with above average standing in the community, actual taxpayers and normally business people, who get excited about such poor performance. Funding is provided for a first-class educational system, 80% of all funds go to teaching salaries/benefits, facilities/staff are deemed well above average and we're churning out a large number of dummies unable to cope with even basic reading. 
 
 The consensus is that the lower percentile, 50%, has little personal motivation, no family support or participation and that school for a majority in that group is viewed as basically a baby-sitting service from grades 1-12. Teachers state that parent/teacher conferences in that group are little more than parents blaming teachers, schools and anything else that sounds like a possible target for the failure of their children. They demand and expect the schools to serve as babysitters, teachers and parents. 
 
 Without student testing and demographic/personal interpretation of the student body, how else would a community determine effectiveness or lack of in its educational system?

My views.
 
 Firstly I don't think there's just one problem as many people seem to be saying. "It's the parents"/ "It's the teachers"/ "It's the money". It's, imo, a combination of pretty much all of these.
 
 To get someone to learn, they need motivation. That should come from the parents. Without that, no amount of money/help is going to make someone a good student. That's, imo, the most important problem.
 
 Once in school, it's the job of the teachers to teach the children: not to baby-sit them. I'm all in favour of having 'sets'. People learn at different rates. Putting people who learn quickly in the same classes with people who learn slowly is, quite simply, moronic. It makes it impossible for the slow kids to keep up, while the fast kids are still slowed down. If someone is mentally disabled it seems pretty pointless to put them in a class with "normal" children. The normal kids will be slowed down, while the disabled kid will have huge problems keeping up.
 
 Onto tests. As I said before, Teachers should teach. That means that they should help the children to learn, not to pass a test. Currently the best ways of doing this, imo, are either hiding the curriculum/what's on the test or having teacher assessments playing a larger role in grades. Both of these have fairly obvious drawbacks, however I feel both of these are better than the current system.
 
 I also feel that teachers should have more legal protection. I have no idea what the situation is in the US, but in the UK the teachers can do very little if there's someone who just doesn't want to learn and only disrupts everyone else.
 
 Now to IT. God how I hate IT in schools. It's ok, if you want to teach basic IT skills to those unfortunate enough not to have a home PC. For the others it's just a chance to ****-around. The time it takes to set up 30computers and keep them running is phenomenal. Personally, I think there should be a few basic IT lessons and then let pupils use the PCs for research under supervision. Other than that, I think the PCs should stay away from school. They cost a lot and are, imo, one of the worst ways to learn.

 I am a retired teacher. I taught at a college. But, I sub now at high schools and middle schools. In Washington D.C. the kids have this system to help them.
 1. If a kid is sick, and has an excused absense, he or she has as many days as he or she was sick, plus one extra day to get the work done and turned into the teachers. 
 2. If the assignment is forgotten, turn it in the next day for half credit (an F) or after that day, it becomes a zero.
 3. Skipping classes to go with your boyfriend, or ditching to hang out with friends, it is considered an unexcused absense. Your parents will be notified, and you will get a zero on all homework assigned that day.
 4. If a student has drug alcohol problems, we have administrators in the building to help.
 5. They have study halls so if the child has that class period open, they have the option of going to the ARC (acedemic resource center) or learning center to get help on assignments.

 If you want your child to be more sucessful, take the following steps:
 1. Make sure your student studies for a minimum of an hour a night. Even if the child has no test, make them read over the chapter in their text books, and study with them.
 2. Have them spend that hour either studying or doing homework. 
 3. Schools hand out planers or logs of what they are expected to record what they didin each of their classes that day. Have them list all their assignments.

 7. Make sure that if a report card still comes in bad, you take televisions away, video games, and everything that your kid does other than his or her homework.
 Parents, if you listen to these steps, your child will be sucessful in school, and will get strait A's and B's like my kids do.

Well, here's how it is here:
 -Public school with 500+ kids in each grade
 -Never more than 30 kids in a class
 -None of my classes (except gym) have more than 20 kids (average class size is probably about 15)
 -AP Calculus 2 is offered in senior year
 -AP history classes can start in 10th grade
 -Math and computer science credits can be earned for a university from 10th grade on
 -Seniors can be enrolled in a community college while in high school so they earn credits
 
 
 I went to a private school through 8th grade. When I started high school, I ended up with a C average in Algebra 2. I even got a D+ in that class at one point. I never had a C in a class before that. The public high school had much higher math standards than the private grade school. We were expected to have learned a lot more in 7th and 8th grade in regards to algebra and geometry than we did. The public school was well ahead of the private school. The private schools around here do not offer college credit for any of their classes. They don't even offer Visual Basic programming or Japanese classes. These are things the public school has offered for at least 5 and 15 years, respectively. Public school students get a much better education that private school students. We can be bussed to a college and take college classes while still in high school for classes that are just entirely beyond the scope of high school. The credits come in handy. And the school pays for the credits. All we buy are books. There are many classes (Calculus, Visual Basic, Java) that are offered with college credits. It costs $135 to get 3 or 4 college credits. We are taught by high school teachers, but the University of Pittsburgh has approved those teachers. Officially, we have attended Pitt and have transcripts from Pitt with our grades. 3 credits from Pitt should cost us over $1000. The private schools don't have that. We have a lot more opportunities to learn than private schools offer.
